Topic.Title: gop will sacrifice the USA for tax cuts to the rich

Message.Msg: here is an accurate account of the mess the gop made: "In 2000, incoming President George Bush took over a booming economy. He inherited a federal budget surplus of $236 billion, an unemployment rate of 4 percent and an average GDP growth rate for the previous four years of 4.4 percent. And the Dow was at 11,250. The economy was as good as it gets. Bush should have dampened the economy with increased taxes. Instead, like most Republicans, he ignored the Keynesian lessons of the Great Depression. He stimulated a bubble economy by cutting taxes and giving away the surplus. Romney's proposals to balance the budget in the midst of a weak economy reflect the same kind of perversity and refusal to learn from history. The Keynesianism that the Republicans reject is straightforward logic. A recession is by definition the existence of idle resources. So you put those resources to work by cutting taxes and increasing spending. Is that so hard to understand? " above from: Romney using Bush's failed playbook By PAUL HEISE Mitt Romney has clinched the Republican nomination, so it's time to ask what a Romney administration would be like. Since everyone agrees that the election will be about the economy, it makes sense to start the campaign off with that. Well, we have a model for what Republican economic policy is like: It is the George W. Bush administration. Bush was elected on the same platform Romney advocates: globalization, deregulation, privatization, and cuts in taxes and government spending."

Message.Title: The Myth of Runaway Health Spending
Message.Msg: Wall Street Journal says we don't need no OvbamaCommieTaxcare! The growth rate of national health expenditures has been declining for a decade, driven by better medical care and consumer choice. New data show that health spending over the past several years has been normalizing toward the rate of general inflation, rather than growing higher and higher, as had been the case almost continuously since the 1970s. This moderation in the growth rate of spending predates the national recession. And it puts the lie to the claim that we need government to put the brakes on an "out-of-control" health-care system. As the graph nearby shows, the growth rate of national health expenditures, according to data compiled by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, has been moderating since 2002. http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052970204792404577227050656680024.html

Topic.Title: Canada: Lower unemployment than USA

Message.Msg: USA has 2nd lowest corporate taxes/gdp in the world: As a share of GDP, the U.S. had the second lowest tax rate, behind only Iceland. This statistic flips on its head the often-repeated Republican charge that America has the second highest corporate tax rate in the world (which is only true on paper). In 2009, U.S. corporate taxes had fallen to only 1.3 percent of GDP, from 4 percent in 1965. "Recently, conservative commentator Bill Kristol chastised his own party for pretending that lowering the corporate tax rate is a cure-all for America’s economic woes. On Fox News Sunday, he interrupted a panelist who again tried to assert the U.S. is suffering from a high corporate tax rate: “Republicans are making a mistake if they focus on big businesses and corporate tax rates. Corporations have a ton of cash. The corporate tax rate is not killing big business in America.” http://www.ctj.org/pdf/oecd201106.pdf

Topic.Title: gop will sacrifice the USA for tax cuts to the rich

Message.Msg: as the father of capitalist theory, Adam Smith pointed out, progressive taxation is essential to capitalism. Most economists agree with that and also add that it is essential for democracy as well. Thomas jefferson said the same: Another means of silently lessening the inequality of property is to exempt all from taxation below a certain point, and to tax the higher portions of property in geometrical progression as they rise. Whenever there is in any country, uncultivated lands and unemployed poor, it is clear that the laws of property have been so far extended as to violate natural right. The earth is given as a common stock for man to labor and live on." --Thomas Jefferson to James Madison, October 28,1785. ME 19:17, Papers 8:682 and isn't this obvious: "the wealthy have a disproportionately greater interest in maintaining societal goods typically supported by taxation such as security of property rights, defense and infrastructure, as they have much more to lose if these fail than do the poor. " You are simply anti American and anti democracy.

Message.Msg: Romney Invested Millions in Firms That Pioneered High-Tech Outsourcing EXCLUSIVE: A government document shows that at Bain he held a $54 million stake in companies that manufactured electronics in China and Mexico for US firms. —By David Corn and Nick Baumann In recent weeks, Barack Obama and Mitt Romney have accused each other of being an "outsourcer in chief," as their campaigns have tussled over Romney's past at Bain Capital and the (non)release of his tax returns. But all this scuffling hasn't taken into account an until-now unreported fact about Romney's days at Bain: When he was running the private equity firm, he invested tens of millions of dollars in a pair of companies that specialized in outsourcing high-tech manufacturing and that developed offshore production facilities in Mexico, China, and elsewhere to build electronics for US firms.

Topic.Title: Mittens an outsourcing king

Message.Msg: The Hill Poll: Majority of voters blame president for bad economy By Sheldon Alberts - 07/23/12 05:00 AM ET Two-thirds of likely voters say the weak economy is Washington’s fault, and more blame President Obama than anybody else, according to a new poll for The Hill. It found that 66 percent believe paltry job growth and slow economic recovery is the result of bad policy. Thirty-four percent say Obama is the most to blame, followed by 23 percent who say Congress is the culprit. Twenty percent point the finger at Wall Street, and 18 percent cite former President George W. Bush. The results highlight the reelection challenge Obama faces amid dissatisfaction with his first-term performance on the economy. The poll, conducted for The Hill by Pulse Opinion Research, found 53 percent of voters say Obama has taken the wrong actions and has slowed the economy down. Forty-two percent said he has taken the right actions to revive the economy, while six percent said they were not sure. Obama has argued throughout the presidential campaign that his policies have made the economy better. He says recovery is taking a long time because he inherited such deep economic trouble upon taking office in 2009. “The problems we’re facing right now have been more than a decade in the making,” he told an audience last month in Cleveland.

Topic.Title: Fiscal Cliff Ahead! No Stopping The Obama Lemmings!

Message.Msg: you forgot the part about, AFTER the 4.4% growth and fisal cliff avoided, then as per the march12 cbo, the debt can be put on a sustainable path by eliminating the bush tax cuts and making some spending cuts: "With that combination of revenues and spending, debt follows a sustainable path—reaching 40 percent of GDP by 2050" March 26, 2012 Current Law Allowing changes that are scheduled under current law to take effect—including the expiration of tax cuts that originally went into effect in 2001 and 2003—is one of many possible approaches for preventing deficits from growing in an unsustainable way. Under that approach, which is the assumption about future policy that underlies CBO’s baseline projections, federal revenues would increase sharply, and federal spending would be restrained somewhat relative to what would occur under current policies; both the revenues and spending of the federal government would be well above their historical averages as a share of GDP. With that combination of revenues and spending, debt follows a sustainable path—reaching 40 percent of GDP by 2050, similar to the average share from 1950 to 2008. http://www.cbo.gov/publication/43134

Topic.Title: Fiscal Cliff Ahead! No Stopping The Obama Lemmings!

Message.Msg: Only you and imbecile Democrats believe this nonsense. 1) Long term growth in USA is 3.0 % to 3.5%. 4.4% growth is 125% higher than the long run average of 3.5%. 2) Ending Bush tax cuts will cause taxes to increase for everyone, pulling money our of the economy and suppressing it, causing a recession or depression. (This is basic Keynesian economics, fool!) I would point out to you that there was a budding recession at the end of Bill Clinton's term in 2000 - 2001 that was CAUSED because the Clinton taxes were building a surplus by drawing money out of the economy and inducing a recession. (This is also basic Keynesian economics, fool!) Bush's tax cuts pumped money back into the economy, leading to growth. (Once again, basic Keynesian economics, fool!) 3) But then we had the Democrat induced credit & housing collapse, which blew our economy into a Depression. (41 months of unemployment over 8%, under Obama, is a DEPRESSION!) 4) The Democrats are also leading us into financial ruin with excessive regulation piling on to of expensive federal health care system, piling on top of refusal to make a reasonable national budget, piling on top of annual deficits of $1.5 trillion and a national debt of around 110% of GDP or $16 trillion. This is really sedition and treason and, at the very least, every Democrat should be thrown out of office, if not in jail!

Topic.Title: Fiscal Cliff Ahead! No Stopping The Obama Lemmings!

Message.Msg: Long run, average, growth of USA economy has been about 3% to 3.5% since about 1900. I've seen those figures starting as from the beginning of the Republic in 1776. Sometimes higher, but our economy is SOOOOOO huge that higher is "not sustainable" for very long without ill effects (inflation.) If we have growth of 2% or less we experience it as a recession and end up with high unemployment. (Example: Current conditions under Obama!) Real growth of 3.5% (without inflation) is about $490 billion per year, which is a LOT of growth. $14.0 trillion * 0.035 = $490.0 billion China has had much faster growth, but they started with almost nothing and are now around $5.8 trillion (per Wikipedia, 2010.) They are the second largest global economy and around 1/3rd of ours. Reports are that they are also having problems managing that much growth that fast.

Topic.Title: Fiscal Cliff Ahead! No Stopping The Obama Lemmings!

Message.Msg: "I proved 4.4% growth is not likely anytime soon" thank you, but i will stick with the professionals at the CBO: How Would Eliminating or Reducing the Fiscal Restraint Affect the Economy in the Short Run? CBO analyzed what would happen if lawmakers changed fiscal policy in late 2012 to remove or offset all of the policies that are scheduled to reduce the federal budget deficit by 5.1 percent of GDP between calendar years 2012 and 2013. In that case, CBO estimates, the growth of real GDP in calendar year 2013 would lie in a broad range around 4.4 percent, well above the 0.5 percent projected for 2013 under current law. http://www.cbo.gov/publication/43262

Topic.Title: Fiscal Cliff Ahead! No Stopping The Obama Lemmings!

Message.Msg: yeah, and for some odd reason you assume spending stays at 9%. and who knows why but you ignore the obvious: " [reducing or eliminating the fiscal restraint would boost economic growth in 2013, but that adopting such a policy without imposing comparable restraint in future years would have substantial economic costs over the longer run." cbo get it? imposing comparable restraint in future years AS PER " that combination of revenues and spending, debt follows a sustainable path—reaching 40 percent of GDP by 2050" March 26, 2012 Current Law Allowing changes that are scheduled under current law to take effect—including the expiration of tax cuts that originally went into effect in 2001 and 2003—is one of many possible approaches for preventing deficits from growing in an unsustainable way. Under that approach, which is the assumption about future policy that underlies CBO’s baseline projections, federal revenues would increase sharply, and federal spending would be restrained somewhat relative to what would occur under current policies; both the revenues and spending of the federal government would be well above their historical averages as a share of GDP. With that combination of revenues and spending, debt follows a sustainable path—reaching 40 percent of GDP by 2050, similar to the average share from 1950 to 2008. http://www.cbo.gov/publication/43134
